title: What is Anzan? The Mental Soroban That Amazes Everyone
description: Anzan is mental soroban – calculating by visualizing an imaginary abacus. It's the ultimate goal of soroban training. Here's how it works.

content.intro: You've seen the videos: a child adding 15 numbers in seconds, fingers moving on an invisible abacus, answering before you can even read the problem. That's anzan – mental soroban. And your child can learn it too.

sections.text: Anzan (暗算) is Japanese for "mental calculation." In the soroban context, it means calculating by visualizing a soroban in your mind – moving imaginary beads instead of physical ones.
Anzan isn't magic or unusual talent. It's a learnable skill that develops naturally from consistent soroban practice.

items: **Step 1:** Learn physical soroban until movements are automatic
**Step 2:** Close eyes and visualize the soroban
**Step 5:** Read the answer from the mental image

sections.text: The physical soroban training is essential. Without it, there's nothing to visualize.
Traditional mental math: "17 + 24... 7 + 4 is 11, carry the 1, 1 + 2 is 3, plus 1 is 4... 41"
Anzan: See 17 as a bead pattern, add 24 pattern, read 41. The verbal/sequential processing is replaced with visual/parallel processing. It's fundamentally different – and faster.

rows: Basic anzan with simple problems (single digit + single digit)

sections.text: These are rough guidelines. Every child progresses differently.

items: **Don't rush it:** Solid physical soroban skills come first
**Try visualization exercises:** "Close your eyes and tell me what 5 looks like on the soroban"
**Use the app's anzan mode:** Structured progression from physical to mental
**Celebrate small wins:** First mental calculation is exciting!
**Be patient:** Anzan develops gradually, not overnight

sections.text: Some kids naturally start visualizing without being told. If you see your child's fingers moving during mental math, they're already doing anzan!

Anzan is impressive, but it's not the only goal. Even kids who don't develop full anzan still benefit enormously from soroban training: better number sense, faster calculation with the physical tool, improved focus and memory.

faq.question: Can all kids learn anzan?
faq.answer: Most can develop some level of anzan with consistent practice. The degree varies – some become extremely proficient, others moderately so.

faq.question: Is anzan only for math prodigies?
faq.answer: No! Anzan is a trained skill, not innate talent. The "amazing" kids in videos simply practiced more. Your child can develop it too.

faq.question: How do I know if my child is visualizing?
faq.answer: Watch their fingers – if they move during mental calculation, they're visualizing. Also, ask them to describe what they "see" when calculating.
